Content: We often start the New Year with a whole bunch of resolutions to change our lives for the better. But what if we started this 2024 with a list of wishes that would make the world a better place for people, animals, and nature alike?   1. May every animal farm close down forever 2. May no activist for social justice be prosecuted or sent to prison for defending lives, exposing cruelty, or speaking up. 3. May no more ancestral lands be devastated for profit. 4. May more laws be passed to restore nature and protect wildlife. 5. May whaling be banned forever, everywhere in the world. 6. May all countries in the world ban wild animal circuses and shows. 7. May technology keep innovating to give us even more plant-based alternatives to all animal products.  What are your wishes and hopes for 2024? Add them in the comments below! ğŸ‘‡

As we get older our eating patterns and behaviors are likely to change. While we can get all the nutrients we need on a vegan diet, there are things to be aware of as we age.  One common change as we get older among all diets is that we tend to eat less, which can lead to insufficient intakes of calcium, iron, zinc, B vitamins, and vitamin E. Even getting sufficient calories can be an issue.  But none of this has to be a problem. Learn more about veganism in older age on our website: genv.org/veganism-for-all/veganism-in-older-age/

Technically, yes you can.  By definition, an environmentalist is a person who is concerned with or advocates for the protection of the environment, and there are a wide range of ways in which a person can do this. Nevertheless, avoiding meat and dairy products is understood to be the single biggest way to reduce our environmental impact on the planet. So while flying less, avoiding single-use plastics, cycling to work, buying food locally, taking shorter showers, and protesting fossil fuels are all effective forms of environmental activism, our ability to protect the planet will only ever be a fraction of what it could be if we continue to consume meat and dairy.  Animal agriculture spans all the multitude of environmental problems, from GHG emissions and biodiversity loss, to deforestation and ocean acidification, so if you're an environmentalist who eats meat, then going vegan is something you should strongly consider. ğŸŒ

This is the reality for millions of pigs worldwide. Mothers are trapped in farrowing crates so small they barely fit. The next litter is born, and the cycle continues.  Animals deserve better. By choosing vegan, we play our role in ending these cruel practices.

ğŸ˜£ Do you know the amount of water it takes to produce meat?  ğŸŒ± Veganism, in addition to being an ethical stance against the systematic suffering experienced by animals, is the fight for a fair food systemâ€”one that does not destroy ancestral landscapes, pollute waterways, or seize land from Indigenous peoples. Bees donâ€™t make honey for us to eat, or just for fun. They do it because they are clever, complex animals who need a source of food over the winter months.  The sugar water that is given to them in lieu of the honey does not contain the essential nutrients and properties bees need to stay optimally healthy and it is believed that this contributes to the mass deaths of bees and the collapse of honey bee colonies.  Bees can feel joy and pain, they express happiness and sorrow. Studies have even shown that they can count and distinguish shapes and even communicate with each other. There are many plant-based alternatives that can be used as sweeteners without hurting the bees.  Video by: @Aimeeswildlifephotos

Here are some things you can expect:  A study found that a healthy plant-based diet helped both the length and heaviness of periods. Participants were found to have a raised SHBG level which means their hormones were better regulated.  A connection between an increase in eating meat and an increase in endometriosis has been found. Symptoms of this painful and debilitating condition may be improved with a plant-based diet. Menopause can be severe, ranging from experiencing tremendous heat all over the body and muscle pain to increased anxiety and a significant loss of bone density. But eating a high-fiber diet that is rich in minimally processed soy, nuts, and seeds can alleviate some of these debilitating impacts.  Eating plant-based has A LOT of health benefits. Did you know that honey is not vegan? #WorldBeeDay  While it may seem like a harmless sweetener, vegans avoid it because it's a product of exploitation and suffering. Here are five reasons why:  1. Honey is made by bees for bees Bees store honey in their hive for the cold winter months when there are no flowers in bloom. Honey is their food.  2. Taking honey from beehives kills bees Bees protect their hives with all their might, but humans smoke them out and gas them so that they can steal honey from the hives. This stresses the bees, makes them disoriented, and can even kill them.  3. Bee farms are cruel After taking the honey, farmers replace it with sugar water. This does not provide the nutrients that bees need, and it reduces their immunity, increasing the risk of sickness and death.  4. Bees are sentient Bees can feel joy and pain, they express happiness and sorrow. Studies have shown that they can count, distinguish shapes, and of course they communicate with each other.  5. Making honey is hard work! Bees painstakingly harvest nectar from thousands of flowers to make honey for themselves. Itâ€™s estimated that bees have to visit two million flowers to make one pound (450g) of honey!  There are many plant-based alternatives that can be used as sweeteners without hurting the bees. Let the bees have their honey.  Let's choose kindness for all creatures, no matter their size ğŸğŸŒ±.

Live export is cruel and unsustainable.  Every year, millions of animals endure a tortuous long-distance journey on ships. They spend weeks confined in cramped conditions, standing or lying in feces and urine, exposed to extreme weather conditions and diseases, only to ultimately face slaughter at the end of this journey. Aside from the intense suffering of animals, this practice also has another impact: environmental.  In live animal export, feces, urine, and even bodies of dead animals are dumped into the ocean without any treatment, polluting and harming marine life. Live export must end.  ğŸ—£ Follow @forum.animal for more information about the protests on June 14th and 15th, in a major action for the International Day Against Live Animal Export!

The dairy industry has many well-kept secrets.ğŸ¤«  We imagine cows and buffaloes are happy to give us their milk and their calves get their share. But many people are not aware of what goes on in dairy farms.   The dairy industry confines cows, denies the calves of their own mothersâ€™ milk, and often starves the calves to death.ğŸ’” Cows and buffaloes from dairy farms end up in slaughter houses.  It happens everywhere. In every single village, city, country.  Go vegan today to stop this injustice.ğŸ™ğŸ½  Go to www.GenV.org to learn more.

Farming animals carries significant implications for our planet and public health, while also inflicting immense suffering on animals. But one often overlooked aspect is the threat it poses to the very people who work in these industries.   While we are often focused on the ethics of meat production, itâ€™s also important to shed light on the risks to those working on farms in slaughterhouses. In this blog, we highlight some of the many risks associated with this kind of occupation.

As we get older our eating patterns and behaviors are likely to change. While we can get all the nutrients we need on a vegan diet, there are things to be aware of as we age.  One common change as we get older among all diets is that we tend to eat less, which can lead to insufficient intakes of calcium, iron, zinc, B vitamins, and vitamin E. Even getting sufficient calories can be an issue.  But none of this has to be a problem. As we get older our eating patterns and behaviors are likely to change. While we can get all the nutrients we need on a vegan diet, there are things to be aware of as we age.  One common change as we get older among all diets is that we tend to eat less, which can lead to insufficient intakes of calcium, iron, zinc, B vitamins, and vitamin E. Even getting sufficient calories can be an issue.  But none of this has to be a problem. Learn more about veganism in older age here: https://genv.pulse.ly/l2dpwmyixh

Does the argument hold if another individual sentient being is harmed in the process?  By adopting a vegan lifestyle, we embrace a higher sense of compassion and responsibility. Mothers are trapped in farrowing crates so small they barely fit. Their babies, born into a world of filthy concrete, are taken away when just a few weeks old and put into overcrowded, barren pens where they are fattened for slaughter. The next litter is born and the cycle continues.  Animals deserve better. By choosing vegan, we play our role in ending these cruel practices.  #pigs #vegan #farm

ğŸŒ±  Chickens raised for their meat, known in the industry as broilers, are slaughtered before they are even 7 weeks old. They never experience life other than that in overcrowded warehouse-style sheds on factory farms.ğŸ”  They have been selectively bred to grow to optimum weights as fast as possible. This has led to unnaturally large-bodied chickens who grow so fast that their legs are unable to support their weight, and their hearts may give out.  ğŸ›‘Globally 70 billion chickens are farmed and killed annually. Yes, vegans can detect traces of animal products in foods with 100% accuracy. Whether it's a hint of dairy in your dessert or a whey protein in your peanut butter, nothing escapes their plant-based radar.  And once you ditch animal products, you'll gain the ability to spot propaganda behind every advertisement showing a happy cow or a milk mustache.  Vegans can also convince even the most dedicated meat-eaters to abandon their meaty ways and embrace tofu with open arms. Resistance is futile in the face of their persuasive plant-based propaganda.  Who needs Marvel when you have vegans?!  What superpowers do you possess?  #VeganFun #Sarcasm #Memes

à¤•à¥‹ à¤•à¥‹à¤ˆ à¤¨à¥à¤•à¤¸à¤¾à¤¨ à¤­à¥€ à¤¨à¤¹à¥€à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¹à¥à¤à¤šà¤¾à¤à¤‚à¤—à¥‡à¥¤  Bees donâ€™t make honey for us to eat, or just for fun. They do it because they are intelligent, complex animals who need a source of food over the winter months.  The sugar water that is given to them in lieu of the honey does not contain the essential nutrients and properties bees need to stay optimally healthy and it is believed that this contributes to the mass deaths of bees and the collapse of honey bee colonies.  Bees can feel joy and pain, they express happiness and sorrow. Studies have shown that they can count, distinguish shapes and communicate with each other. There are many plant-based alternatives that can be used as sweeteners without hurting the bees.  Video by: @Aimeeswildlifephotos

A mother's love for her baby is just as profound as the affection an animal has for her offspring. How â€œnaturalâ€ is your life?  Why do some people argue that killing animals is "natural" when most of us do not hunt or gather, but instead buy our food pre-packaged from a supermarket? Thatâ€™s not exactly natural!  We are not confined to the same life-or-death struggle that exists daily in nature. We have modern amenities, many more choices, and a greater understanding of our world than our prehistoric ancestors. ğŸ¤¨ğŸŒ± Many times we have heard this myth, sometimes as a genuine doubt, sometimes to discredit veganism. What we know is that plants do NOT feel like animals, including humans; they do not have a brain and there is not enough evidence of any kind of "brain center" in the root, as some have claimed.  While plants communicate with each other, this does not indicate a sense of self or others, and does not imply consciousness. On the other hand, animals are conscious, definitely feel pain, and clearly show their individuality, personality, and agency. A heartbreaking report of the realities of factory farms in India.

Modern egg farms keep tens of thousands of female birds â€“ usually chickens â€“ incarcerated in order to efficiently harvest the eggs that they lay.   Efficiency is everything because farming is a business and every cent spent is tightly controlled. Once they cannot keep up with the demand, they are slaughtered.  Just for a second imagine their lives- being trapped in metal cages, with no space to even spread their wings, riddled with diseases because they live in filthy conditions all for an egg.ğŸ’”  #veganforlife #govegan #veganegg #eggfree

Our appetite places an enormous burden on aquatic animals. Fish and other sea life are killed in much higher numbers than land animals but their stories remain underreported.   Most aquatic species are measured by the tonne, not by number of bodies, so exact figures are impossible to know and opportunities to connect with them as individuals capable of pain and suffering are sparse.

The meat industry has long worked to downplay the connection between meat and climate change and, at least so far, itâ€™s working.   A study Sentient Media conducted earlier this year with Faunalytics found 93 percent of climate coverage did not mention the meat-climate connection.  But here's a great list of studies put together by them to show otherwise.

One person canâ€™t solve the climate crisis of course, but research from Project Drawdown shows household actions can add up to make a big difference.   Still, that doesnâ€™t mean climate anxiety should stop you from celebration.   This year, try these tips for making it a more sustainable holiday celebration!

Recipe   Lemon Carlota    ğŸ‹You will need:   3 packs of silken tofu (1kg) 3/4 cup lemon juice 3/4 cup sugar 3 teaspoons vanilla extract 2 and 1/2 packets of your favourite vegan cookies/wafer biscuits  Directions: ğŸ‹Add all the ingredients except the cookies to the blender, and process very well until you get a super creamy texture. In your mold or dessert pan, make a layer of cookies at the bottom. Add a layer of the tofu cream to cover the cookies. On top of the tofu add another layer of cookies and cover them with another layer of tofu. Continue like this until you finish with a layer of tofu on top. Let it sit in the refrigerator overnight.  ğŸ‹The next day decorate with a little lemon zest and leftover cookies. from her mother. She has been deprived of it because we need our chai, coffee and cheese.  The only reason she is kept alive is because she is a female. Male calves are of no use to the dairy industry and are â€œdiscardedâ€.  She will be put through the same cycle as her mother. She will be artificially impregnated so that she can be milked and her child be taken away from her.   This cycle will go on until her body can no longer take it.  Then she will be sold for slaughter.  Did you know buffaloes are responsible for 31% of Indiaâ€™s dairy production.  We can break this cycle by choosing to give up dairy and go vegan. The pattern is unmistakable. News stories describe massive sheds packed with animals flooded or consumed by fire, leading to millions of deaths, but most of these media accounts fail to ask what might happen next time.   Thatâ€™s no accidental omission.   When farmed animals are considered part of property, the laws around them tend to favour humans more.

Veal meat is the flesh of a baby cow, who has arguably endured more suffering in his short life than many others on our planet may ever endure in a lifetime.
